Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Who's Not at the Table? Building Research Capacity for Underserved Communities in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop proposal focuses on developing a national agenda for research in broadening participation in engineering by those who self-identify as persons with disabilities, veterans, low income/first generation or members of the LGBTQ community. The effort to increase the numbers of students who study computer science and engineering is a national imperative. Furthermore, there is a need to ensure this workforce is representative of the nation's populations as a diverse workforce will spark greater innovation and creativity through the incorporation of multiple perspectives and experiences in the creation of technology. Efforts to create a more diverse workforce have often focused on interventions to recruit and retain under-represented populations. As a result progress has not occurred at a substantial rate as these efforts tend to be localized and not easily scaled. What is needed is greater research in understanding the various factors that impede and influence the full participation of these underserved groups.

The project will convene a workshop of thought leaders, including scholars, practitioners, policy makers and others from a broad spectrum of social science disciplines. Brought together from across the nation, the participants will seek to develop an understanding of how best to increase research capacity to better understand why these groups are so underrepresented in the computer science and engineering workforce. Participants will identify existing research and new research possibilities regarding computing and engineering participation by persons from the specified under-served groups. The goal is to help define the national agenda for areas of research in the field of broadening participation for these targeted populations in the engineering and computer science workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to develop and disseminate a research agenda on broadening engineering participation by persons self-identifying as those with disabilities; veterans; low income/first-generation persons; and persons of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or queer identity. First, we held a working conference of 70 scholars, practitioners, policy makers, and other thought leaders with diverse backgrounds in terms of geographical location, research areas, personal identities, institution type, position at their institution, and level of research experience. The resulting dialogue represented a groundbreaking opportunity for participants to contribute to creating a national agenda for research for broadening participation. We organized conference activities around five themes (theories, methods, research questions, practices and experiences, and knowledge needed to improve educational practices). A panel discussion, breakout sessions, structured and unstructured time for reflection, small group exercises, a poster session, and meals centered around discussions of these five themes. We collected data describing participants’ recommendations for improving capacity for broadening participation research during each of the various activities. Following the working conference, we published conference proceedings and gave several national presentations related to both the process of hosting an inclusive event and the content of the working conference. We analyzed the participant-generated data and distilled recommendations first into a white paper, and later, into the first draft of a research agenda. Using the draft agenda based on the working conference, we engaged additional scholars from the engineering education research community to refine the text as a position paper for publication. The document presents our recommendations for broadening participation research; we call for researchers to consider the role of theory, methods, and research questions and provide examples of ways this could be accomplished.

A secondary goal of the working conference was to build capacity for broadening participation in engineering through the development and strengthening of professional networks research and practice. Results from social network analysis of conference attendees showed that conference activities facilitated the exchange of information and resources among participants.
